newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait Oil Co union says considering strike in May.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait Oil Co union says considering strike in May.

text.p: Kuwait Oil Co (KOC) workers union said on Thursday it was considering a possible strike in May over a dispute with the state-owned firm about promotions.
"If there was no solution next month...there could be a strike," union chairman Mohammad al-Sarahan told Reuters.
"Now we are in talks with the (KOC) officials."
Sarhan said: "If the circumstances required and we found a firm stance from the management of the company (KOC)...there would be a strike."
"Things here are going towards aggravation because the issue of (workers') grades, over which the 1995 strike took place, is not over yet despite promises by officials."
In March 1995 the union launched a strike aimed at halting Kuwait's three percent share of world production to demand a reshuffle of employment grades.
There are some 750 KOC export, maintenance, and gas operations workers whose working conditions needed to be fixed, he said.
KOC is the production arm of the state-owned conglomerate Kuwait Petroleum Corp (KPC) which oversees the oil industry.
"We are in talks with the Ministry of Social Affairs and Labour," he said. The Ministry mediates between workers and employers in labour disputes.
OPEC member Kuwait produces about 2.0 million barrels of crude per day.
A senior KOC official said he would not comment on the matter "until the company recieves details from the union about the subject."
